Flat and level.
examples: Clear out those rocks. The surface must be even.

senses.sense: Without great variation.
examples: Despite her fear, she spoke in an even voice.

senses.sense: Equal in proportion, quantity, size, etc.
examples: The distribution of food must be even.
Call it even.

senses.sense: (not comparable, of an integer) Divisible by two.
examples: Four, fourteen and forty are even numbers.

senses.sense: (of a number) Convenient for rounding other numbers to; for example, ending in a zero.
On equal monetary terms; neither owing nor being owed.
(colloquial) On equal terms of a moral sort; quits.
examples: You biffed me back at the barn, and I biffed you here—so now we're even.

senses.sense: Parallel; on a level; reaching the same limit.
(obsolete) Without an irregularity, flaw, or blemish; pure.
(obsolete) Associate; fellow; of the same condition.
(transitive) To make flat and level.
examples: We need to even this playing field; the west goal is too low.

senses.sense: (transitive, obsolete) To equal or equate; to make the same.
(intransitive, obsolete) To be equal.
examples: Thrice nine evens twenty seven.

senses.sense: (transitive, obsolete) To place in an equal state, as to obligation, or in a state in which nothing is due on either side; to balance, as accounts; to make quits.
examples: We need to even the score.

senses.sense: (transitive, obsolete) To set right; to complete.
(transitive, obsolete) To act up to; to keep pace with.
(archaic) Exactly, just, fully.
examples: I fulfilled my instructions even as I had promised.
You are leaving tonight? — Even so.
This is my commandment, that ye love one another, even as I have loved you.

senses.sense: In reality; implying an extreme example in the case mentioned, as compared to the implied reality.
examples: Even a blind squirrel finds an acorn sometimes.
Did you even make it through the front door?
That was before I was even born.

senses.sense: Emphasizing a comparative.
examples: I was strong before, but now I am even stronger.

senses.sense: Signalling a correction of one's previous utterance; rather, that is.
examples: My favorite actor is Jack Nicklaus. Jack Nicholson, even.

senses.sense: (mathematics, diminutive) An even number.
examples: So let's see. There are two evens here and three odds.

examples: an evil beast; an evil plant; an evil crop

senses.sense: (computing, programming, slang) Undesirable; harmful; bad practice.
examples: Global variables are evil; storing processing context in object member variables allows those objects to be reused in a much more flexible way.

senses.sense: Moral badness; wickedness; malevolence; the forces or behaviors that are the opposite or enemy of good.
examples: The evils of society include murder and theft.
Evil lacks spirituality, hence its need for mind control.

senses.sense: Something which impairs the happiness of a being or deprives a being of any good; something which causes suffering of any kind to sentient beings; harm; injury; mischief.
(obsolete) A malady or disease; especially in combination, as in king's evil, colt evil.
(obsolete) wickedly, evilly, iniquitously
(obsolete) injuriously, harmfully; in a damaging way.
(obsolete) badly, poorly; in an insufficient way.
examples: It went evil with him.

senses.sense: A person who performs evil acts.
plural of evildoer
An evil or wicked act, especially a crime.
comparative form of evil: more evil
superlative form of evil: most evil
comparative form of evil: more evil
superlative form of evil: most evil
In an evil manner.
The quality or state of being evil.
plural of evilness
plural of evil
(slang) the evil eye
examples: Don't go giving me evils!

manifestation

To render weak or unmanly.

(transitive) To disembowel, to remove the viscera.
(transitive) To destroy or make ineffectual or meaningless.

third-person singular simple present indicative form of eviscerate

A disemboweling; the removal of viscera.
examples: The evisceration of the animal was accomplished with a single blow of the knife.

senses.sense: (figurative, by extension) A vigorous verbal or physical assault.
examples: The critic delivered another evisceration of the latest movie.

senses.sense: plural of evisceration
Someone who eviscerates, whether physically or metaphorically.
A device for eviscerating something.
(uncommon) Possible to avoid; avertible.
examples: The tragic consequences were evitable.

That which evokes (brings to mind) a memory, mood, idea, feeling, or image; redolent or reminiscent.
In an evocative manner.
The state or condition of being evocative
Someone who evokes.

Evoking something; evocative.
Relating to evocation.
(dated) A female evocator.
Alternative form of euoi ("Bacchic cry")
To call out; to draw out or bring forth.
To cause the manifestation of something (emotion, picture, etc.) in someone's mind or imagination.
examples: Being here evokes long forgotten memories.
Seeing this happen equally evokes fear and anger in me.
The book evokes a detailed and lively picture of what life was like in the 19th century.

(geometry) A curve comprising the centres of curvature of another curve.
(malacology) Having or being a (mollusc) spiral shell in which the whorls touch along a surface.
plural of evolute
A change of position.
(military) A manoeuvre of troops or ships.
(chiefly dance, sports) A turning movement, especially of the body.
(obsolete) A turned or twisted shape; an involution, a complex or intricate shape.
An unfolding.
(now rare) The act or process of unfolding or opening out; the progression of events in regular succession.
(geometry) The opening out of a curve; now more generally, the gradual transformation of a curve by a change of the conditions generating it.
(mathematics, now chiefly historical) The extraction of a root from a given power.
(chemistry) The act or an instance of giving off gas; emission.
Process of development.
Development; the act or result of developing what was implicit in an idea, argument etc.
examples: The ongoing evolution of Lolita subculture fashion includes, among other things, the ballet style.

senses.sense: A process of gradual change in a given system, subject, product etc., especially from simpler to more complex forms.
examples: Among other forms of change, the evolution of transportation has involved modification, diversification, convergence, divergence, hybridization, differentiation, and naturally, selection.

senses.sense: (biology) The transformation of animals, plants and other living things into different forms (now understood as a change in genetic composition) by the accumulation of changes over successive generations.
Of or pertaining to evolution, or coming about as a result of the principles of evolution.
examples: Man is the probable evolutional successor to the chimpanzee.

senses.sense: In an evolutional manner
With regard to evolution
In a manner relating to evolution or slow development.
(domain, evolutionary theory) From the perspective of evolution.
Of or relating to the biological theory of evolution.
examples: The evolutionary history of marine mammals includes land-dwelling ancestors.

senses.sense: Having formal similarities to the biological theory of evolution.
(countable) Any of several theories that explain the evolution of systems or organisms.
(uncountable) The belief in the universal presence of evolution.
(uncountable) The advocacy of Darwinian evolution by natural selection (Darwinism).
A proponent or supporter of evolutionism.
Of or pertaining to evolutionism.
In an evolutionistic manner
plural of evolutionist
To cause, or to undergo change by means of evolution; to evolve
plural of evolution
Of, pertaining to, or advocating evolution or development; evolutionary
Capable of evolving.
That can be drawn out.
(transitive) To move (something) in regular procession through a system.
(transitive) To change or transform (something).
examples: What began as a few lines of code has now evolved into a million-line behemoth.

senses.sense: (transitive) To cause (something) to come into being or develop.
(transitive) (biology) Of a population: to acquire or develop (a trait) in the process of biological evolution.
examples: How long ago did birds evolve beaks?

senses.sense: (transitive) (biology) (chiefly passive) To cause (a population, a species, etc.) to change genetic composition over successive generations through the process of evolution.
examples: A hundred thousand years from now, will Homo sapiens have evolved into beings unrecognizable to their ancestors?

senses.sense: (transitive) (chemistry) To give off (a gas such as carbon dioxide or oxygen) during a chemical reaction.
examples: to evolve odours

senses.sense: (transitive) (obsolete) To wind or unwind (something).
(intransitive) To move in regular procession through a system.
(intransitive) To change, to transform.
(intransitive) (biology) Of a trait; to develop within a population through biological evolution.
examples: How long ago did beaks evolve?
